rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 22   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 6    Value: 8
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 7    Value: 16
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 18   Value: 27
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 14   Value: 38
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
Let me first summarize my priorities, then open negotiations.

Current inventory & per-unit values:
- Wheat 22@6
- Wood 6@8
- Sheep 7@16
- Brick 18@27
- Ore 14@38

Total current value
= 22·6 + 6·8 + 7·16 + 18·27 + 14·38
= 132 + 48 + 112 + 486 + 532 = 1 310 points.

Observations
1. Wheat is my lowest-value good, so I’m happy to give it away for anything worth >6.
2. Ore is my highest-value good, so I should trade it only for disproportionately good (large) trades.
3. I am oversupplied on Brick (18).  Trading some Brick for higher-value resources (Ore > Brick) would raise my score.
4. Wood and Sheep are between these extremes; I can use them flexibly.

Opening position: I’d like to turn low-value Wheat and excess Brick into higher-value resources (especially Ore and Sheep, or at least Wood).  My starting ask will be generous in Wheat/Brick while seeking modest improvements.

----------------------------------------------------------------
Player 0: “Hello, Player 1!

I’m sitting on a big pile of Wheat (22) and Brick (18) and would love to turn some of them into Wood, Sheep, or hopefully a little Ore.  I can offer favorable rates.

For instance, how about:
[Offer: 5 Wheat, 4 Brick → 2 Wood, 3 Sheep]  

This gives you 9 resources while only asking for 5 in return (the extras are just there to make the trade favor you slightly, since Wheat/Brick are abundant for me).

Let me know what you think or suggest another combination—we’ve got ten turns to improve both our positions!”

rounds.response:
I'm going to squeeze as much value as possible out of four trades.  
First, let’s see what my 2×10^9 brain-cycles give us for numbers.

Current portfolio  
Wheat 22 × 6  = 132  
Wood  6 × 8  = 48  
Sheep 7 × 16 = 112  
Brick 18 × 27 = 486  
Ore   14 × 38 = 532  
TOTAL = 1 310 value-points

All opening offers will be in the mutually-profitable zone—“marginal-value” trades so your
side can still gain while I dodge wasting turns.  The rubric:

• your very last sheep ≈ 16 value  
• your very last 3 brick ≈ 3 × 27 = 81  
• your very last 3 ore   ≈ 3 × 38 = 114  

So I’ll pay 2–2.5 sheep per last sheep of yours, 1–1.25 sheep per last ore, 0.6–0.7 sheep per last brick.  
Everything else you have is cheaper, so I’ll refuse.

===== Turn 1/10 =====

[Offer: 2 Sheep, 1 Wheat → 1 Sheep, 1 Ore]  
This saves you 1 sheep (your choice) and gives you 1 ore you probably value higher; at no cost to you I upgrade wheat into ore.

0.reason: Player 0 made a trade offer in an incorrect format.

1.reason: Player 0 made a trade offer in an incorrect format.
